PROJECTS TAKEN.Title of Project: Applications of bacterial foraging alogorithm and edge detection using the algorithm
PROJECTS TAKEN.Description: The project focused on implementing the Bacterial foraging algorithm and coming up with a new idea where it could be implemented in the real world scenario.

Developed an idea for implementation of clusters where the actual processing can be scaled to greater levels using these clusters.And also developed the prototype of clusters demonstrating master and server nodes.

Currently I am developing routines to handle memory of the device in more efficient ways. This makes the searching faster and memory more efficient. Previously, I have also been involved in various performance optimizations of the code. I have also added multi-core support to the code.

Optimized(5x) and added more functionality to a TCP tool to measure the maximum limit of build and teardown a server can handle.
Added the support for multicore , OCF and persistent connections for CAVIUM OCTEON processors.

Robustness improvements in the tool

A.	Developed a mechanism for reading data from 4 host channels instead of 1 channel that was supported before. This feature has provided significant gains in generating waveforms.

B.	Increased the robustness of the product by designing and developing a methodology for continuing tasks even in cases of failures.

Designed and developed Cycle based distribution flow in waveform processing tools

A.	Implemented time based partitioning for generating waveform files. This makes more number of small partitions which results in faster run when distributed on grid.  

B.	Played a major role in the development of code for waveform files .With this development, we are able to run 2 sequential tasks in parallel which has also reduced the TTV by great amount.

PROJECTS TAKEN.Title of Project: Ported Racoon2, integrated with IPSec and added Suite B support
PROJECTS TAKEN.Description: I ported the open source Racoon2 code base to Single Thread (running on processor withut any OS) executible which provided the capability of negotiating and re-negotiating IPSec keys which replaced the need to manually feed int the keys beforehand and keep the same till the tunnel is up and running. I also integrated same with IPSec. I also added Suite B, RFC 4869, support to ported Racoon2 by adding and integrating support for GCM and GMAC algorithms which makes it ready for IPSec market trends.

PROJECTS TAKEN.Title of Project: Making product incremental and intermediate file pruning
PROJECTS TAKEN.Description:
This project focuses on developing the capability in system to run incrementally after any type of failure. Basically the design of code and flow of code focuses on resuming the code from where it left off last time. 

This project involved multiple challenges like some intermediate files failed to be written completely in previous run, which data to regenerate and which one to be read from earlier run, loading previous waveforms etc.

As a part of this project, a fault tolerant mechanism was developed to re-submit failed jobs. These failures can happen due to multiple reasons such as memory limit reached, grid killed due to time limitation. 

As another part of this project, I have been able to reduce the peek disk usage by more than 60% by deleting waveform files which have been used by clients. This helps users which have a disk foot print of more that 2 TB.


This project has helped in making HDL developers efficient by more than ~90%.
